Award.AwardTitle: Enhancing infrastructure for multidisciplinary, long-term research at the Karisoke Research Center, Rwanda
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Karisoke Research Center (KRC) in Rwanda (www.gorillafund.org) is the world's largest and longest running continuous field site for studying gorillas in the wild. Data collected at Karisoke has contributed to nearly 300 scientific publications on gorillas and the surrounding region on topics ranging from socioecology, life history, paternal and maternal investment, ontogeny, physiology, health, feeding ecology, evolutionary biology, and genetics. Over the past five years, 47 researchers from 17 universities, including undergraduate, graduate students, postdocs, and faculty, have also conducted research at Karisoke and data from Karisoke has been used in collaborations with more than 40 institutions. Despite the long-term success of Karisoke as a research site, its facilities are not currently adequate to support this range of inquiry and demonstrate the limitations of ad hoc field facilities. Particularly, the laboratory and herbarium are desperately in need of refurbishment. These facilities lack adequate sanitation, ventilation, and the organizational capacity to store samples. This improvement project will provide the infrastructure needed for broad interdisciplinary research in the fields of endocrinology, genetics, disease ecology, and conservation biology. The primary outcomes will be an improved laboratory facility to advance innovative, interdisciplinary research, and a high-functioning herbarium, including a digital archive, to aid national and global collaborative research to better understand the increasing changes to the region's flora. In addition, improvements to these facilities will be utilized by visiting researchers around the world, as well as by host-country researchers (undergraduate and graduate students, and scientists), where there is a great need for next generation scientists.

The need for a modern Karisoke laboratory facility has been growing over the past 15 years and has become acute in the last five years as vast developments in new lab techniques and a need for increasingly interdisciplinary research has emerged. To improve working conditions for laboratory staff and visiting researchers, and to meet international laboratory standards, multiple laboratory workspace upgrades are needed for processing and preserving fecal samples for hormones (metabolites), particle size, isotope, microbiome analysis, and molecular work, and or parasitological analyses and phytolite studies, which require up-to-date imaging microscopes. Additional improvements include installing exhume hood exhaust systems along with refrigeration units and storage for samples. The KRC herbarium will be reconstructed into a biological sample storage room with state of the art storage and climate control measures. A drying preservation stage will be installed in a separate room to reduce the risk of contamination. These improvements will make the collection of plant species more sustainable, accessible, and usable to visiting researchers to study the diverse Virunga massif vegetation, and will allow for the expansion of the plant collection (and potentially other voucher collections).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Karisoke Research Center in Rwanda is the world’s largest and longest running continuous field site for studying gorillas in the wild. Established in 1967 by Dian Fossey and named in honor of the two nearby volcanoes, Karisimbi and Bisoke, Karsioke is an internationally recognized field primatology site for the study of the Virunga mountain gorillas (Gorilla beringei beringei).

Over the last 50 years, the Karisoke Research Center has collected critical data pertaining to gorillas and the surrounding biodiversity that has contributed to more than 300 scientific publications on topics ranging from socioecology, life history, paternal and maternal investment, ontogeny, physiology, health, feeding ecology, evolutionary biology, and genetics. Despite the long-term success of Karisoke as a research site, its facilities were inadequate to support this range of inquiry. Particularly, the laboratory and herbarium were desperately in need of refurbishment. These facilities lacked adequate sanitation, ventilation, and the organizational capacity to store samples. Improvements to the laboratory were requested to provide the infrastructure needed for broad interdisciplinary research in the fields of endocrinology, genetics, disease ecology, and conservation biology.

 

Intellectual Merit: The Karisoke Research Center collects important scientific research on gorilla behavior, ecology, and conservation. This repository of long-term data continues to be one of the largest databases of information on any animal and the source for much of the scientific knowledge on gorillas today. What makes the research center so unique is the amount and detail of data that can be obtained. More than 110 individual gorillas are observed daily with family tree data dating back five generations. This enables a host of complex questions about life history, behavior, genetic, hormones, evolution, and ecology and the linkages between them.

 

Project Outcome: This project enabled an upgrade to our laboratory facilities—specifically our biological samples lab and herbarium. The primary outcome is an improved laboratory facility and safer working conditions, providing climate controlled facilities to maintain a herbarium of more than 2000 samples for over 800 plant species (of 85 families). Our herbarium will greatly contribute to the knowledge of the flora of the region including the Volcanoes National Park and Gishwati National Park, the main spots of our research. The Fossey Fund herbarium is a unique source of information which will complement the existing collection at the National Herbarium of the Center of Excellence in Biodiversity in Rwanda.

Improvements to these facilities are utilized by visiting researchers from around the world. In addition, we depend on these facilities as an integral part of our capacity building program. The Fossey Fund has developed one of the most robust training programs for African scientists in the region, hosting approximately 400 undergraduate students each year at our research center for classroom and field-based courses, along with doctoral candidates and post docs for professional internships and research fellowships. Using these new facilities and state of the art equipment will assist our role in preparing the next generation of conservation leaders.
